title: Sri Lanka cabinet approves 2.5-pct turnover tax
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s cabinet of ministers has approved a bill to impose a 2.5 percent turnover tax on companies, a government statement said.
The tax, styled social contribution levy, will be charged on companies with an annual turnover of 120 million rupees or more.
It will apply to importers, manufacturers, service providers, wholesalers and retailers.
Business chambers and economic analysts have criticized the levy as a cascading tax and had said it was better to increase the value added tax to cover revenue shortfalls.
Sri Lanka in 2019 cut value added tax from 15 to 8 percent and abolished a cascading turnover tax.
Cascading taxes tend to push up prices exponentially at each stage of value addition but can bring more revenues while creating distortions.
Sri Lanka is now struggling to find money to pay its bloated state workers after two years of money printing led to a currency collapse and high inflation.
State worker salaries were also raised in early 2021 by then Finance Minister Basil Rajapsaksa despite revenue problems. (Colombo/June14/2022)
